projectPurpose: To provide a single, high-performance, scalable, and cost-effective database solution for storing and analyzing all types of observability data (metrics, logs, and traces) in cloud-native and distributed environments, simplifying the data stack with unified query languages (SQL, PromQL) and streaming capabilities.
mainFeatures: Unified database for metrics, logs, and traces
Written in Rust for high performance
Optimized columnar storage and rich indexing
Separated compute and storage, supports object storage
High scalability and performance for large datasets
Supports various data ingestion protocols and access methods (REST, MySQL/PostgreSQL protocols)
Available as a managed cloud service (GreptimeCloud)

alternatives.name: InfluxDB
mainFeatures: Native SQL and InfluxQL query languages

alternatives.name: Prometheus
mainFeatures: HTTP pull model for metrics collection

alternatives.name: TimescaleDB
alternatives.license: Open Source (Apache 2.0 for Apache 2 Edition), Source Available (Timescale License for Community Edition), Proprietary (Cloud/Enterprise)
platforms: Cross-platform (Linux, macOS, Windows, Docker, Cloud) - Built on PostgreSQL
mainFeatures: Extends PostgreSQL for time series data

alternatives.name: Elasticsearch
alternatives.license: Dual-licensed (SSPL and Elastic License - proprietary/source-available), AGPL for core components
mainFeatures: Often used for log aggregation and analysis

alternatives.name: SigNoz
mainFeatures: Unified UI for metrics, logs, and traces

marketPositioning: GreptimeDB is positioned as a unified, cloud-native, and high-performance observability database that converges metrics, logs, and traces into a single system. It differentiates itself from traditional approaches that rely on separate databases for each data type (e.g., Prometheus for metrics, Elasticsearch for logs) by offering a simplified architecture, unified query languages (SQL and PromQL), and a focus on performance at scale using Rust and columnar storage with object storage integration. Its open-source Apache 2.0 license provides a distinct advantage over some alternatives with more restrictive licensing models. It competes with specialized time-series databases, analytical databases used for observability, and other unified observability backends, aiming to provide a more efficient and cost-effective solution for modern distributed systems.
